awd_titl_txt: Alliance of Scientific Societies for the Development of the Next Generation of Scientists
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on building a diverse scientific workforce inclusive of underrepresented minorities by coordinating and integrating the efforts of professional scientific societies. The Alliance of Scientific Societies for the Development of the Next Generation of Scientists will draw upon insights and principles from the field of social science to build a Community of Practice by unifying and integrating the established effective practices for inclusion and diversity within a large group of national and international scientific societies based in the US. The goals of this Alliance are to create innovative, effective and strategic plans across organizations to offer members of minorities the opportunity to participate in the scientific enterprise, and to establish robust programs for the recruitment and retention of a diverse scientific workforce. A set of best practices and evaluation metrics will be developed and made available to the scientific community by a variety of mechanisms including conferences, workshops and on-line databases.

Findings from the social sciences (drawing upon research in communities of practice, social cognitive career theory, identity formation, and cultural capital) provide insights into how underrepresented minority scientists develop, make choices, and meet challenges. This project will bring together the Minority Affairs and Diversity Committees of participating scientific societies along with social science professionals  and other stakeholders to integrate their knowledge and experience to create and disseminate a unified database of diversity programs, a standard reference set of evaluation metrics, and create a context in which to share resources, best practices, and program outcomes to broaden participation of underrepresented minorities in the scientific enterprise.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Fostering inclusion and facilitating the professional development of underrepresented minorities (URMs) plays an essential role in the efforts of scientific societies within Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). However, lack of communication and a lack of a centralized repository for best practices can result in effort duplication and lead to sub-optimal initiatives and approaches. 


The goal of this project, and of the Alliance to Catalyze Change for Equity in STEM Success (ACCESS), was to develop a platform for scientific societies within STEM to collect, discuss, and share tools and resources that will help them address the needs and concerns of URM in different disciplines. To this end, the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB), the American Society for Cell Biology (ASCB), the American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (ASPET), the Biophysical Society (BPS), The Endocrine Society (TES), and the Scientific Careers Research and Development Group (SCRDG) at Northwestern University joined efforts to build a Community of Practice (C of P) to support future interactions that will lead to collaborative programs and initiatives to share data and best practices, not only between these societies, but with the community at large, to effectively and efficiently train the next generation of diverse scientists.


ACCESS successfully developed a database and website (www.stemaccessforall.org/) to integrate data from multiple sources and ensure optimal dissemination of best practices. Some of these practices included travel award programming, speaker diversity, and more. The findings were disseminated through a variety of platforms:


1. ACCESS website and database. 

2. Peer-reviewed publications. 

3. Poster and oral conference presentations.

4. Invited talks.

5. Publications on society websites and newsletters. 

6. Social media.


ACCESS successfully provided guidelines and metrics to determine the level of success of different programmatic activities implemented by different scientific societies aimed at broadening participation of URMs in STEM. Overall, this project provided proof of principle that a diversity-focused meta-organization composed of scientific societies is a productive endeavor capable of enacting change and diversifying the STEM workforce.
